title: Price Expectations as a Determinant of Demand

content.question: Country <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a major buyer of Country <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>’s grains. Assume Country <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>’s government announced an increase in taxes on its imports of Country <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>’s grains effective next month. How will this news likely affect consumers’ demand for grains in Country <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: It will increase now because the tax on imported grains will increase the future price of grains.
It will decrease now because the tax on imported grains will increase the future price of grains.
It will not change now because the tax on imported grains will increase the future price of grains.
It will increase now because the tax on imported grains will increase the current price of grains.
It will decrease now because the tax on imported grains will increase the current price of grains.

content.answer: It will increase now because the tax on imported grains will increase the future price of grains.
